trans-unit.source: Tips for using Hadoop on Linux-based HDInsight | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Tips for using Hadoop on Linux-based HDInsight | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Get implementation tips for using Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) clusters on a familiar Linux environment running in the Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: Get implementation tips for using Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) clusters on a familiar Linux environment running in the Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: Information about using HDInsight on Linux (preview)
trans-unit.target: Information about using HDInsight on Linux (preview)

trans-unit.source: Linux-based Azure HDInsight clusters provide Hadoop on a familiar Linux environment, running in the Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: Linux-based Azure HDInsight clusters provide Hadoop on a familiar Linux environment, running in the Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: For most things, it should work exactly as any other Hadoop-on-Linux installation.
trans-unit.target: For most things, it should work exactly as any other Hadoop-on-Linux installation.

trans-unit.source: This document calls out specific differences that you should be aware of.
trans-unit.target: This document calls out specific differences that you should be aware of.

trans-unit.source: Domain names
trans-unit.target: Domain names

trans-unit.source: The fully qualified domain name (FQDN) to use when connecting to the cluster is .azurehdinsight.net or (for SSH only) .azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: The fully qualified domain name (FQDN) to use when connecting to the cluster is .azurehdinsight.net or (for SSH only) .azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: Remote access to services
trans-unit.target: Remote access to services

trans-unit.source: Ambari (web) - https://.azurehdinsight.net
trans-unit.target: Ambari (web) - https://.azurehdinsight.net

trans-unit.source: Authenticate by using the cluster administrator user and password, and then log in to Ambari.
trans-unit.target: Authenticate by using the cluster administrator user and password, and then log in to Ambari.

trans-unit.source: This also uses the cluster administrator user and password.
trans-unit.target: This also uses the cluster administrator user and password.

trans-unit.source: Authentication is plaintext - always use HTTPS to help ensure that the connection is secure.
trans-unit.target: Authentication is plaintext - always use HTTPS to help ensure that the connection is secure.

trans-unit.source: While Ambari for your cluster is accessible directly over the Internet, some functionality relies on accessing nodes by the internal domain name used by the cluster.
trans-unit.target: While Ambari for your cluster is accessible directly over the Internet, some functionality relies on accessing nodes by the internal domain name used by the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Since this is an internal domain name, and not public, you will receive "server not found" errors when trying to access some features over the Internet.
trans-unit.target: Since this is an internal domain name, and not public, you will receive "server not found" errors when trying to access some features over the Internet.

trans-unit.source: To work around this problem, use an SSH tunnel to proxy web traffic to the cluster head node.
trans-unit.target: To work around this problem, use an SSH tunnel to proxy web traffic to the cluster head node.

trans-unit.source: Use the SSH tunneling section of the following articles to create an SSH tunnel from a port on your local machine to the cluster:
trans-unit.target: Use the SSH tunneling section of the following articles to create an SSH tunnel from a port on your local machine to the cluster:

trans-unit.source: Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X: Steps on creating an SSH tunnel by using the ssh command.
trans-unit.target: Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X: Steps on creating an SSH tunnel by using the ssh command.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>: Steps on using PuTTY to create an SSH tunnel.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>: Steps on using PuTTY to create an SSH tunnel.

trans-unit.source: Ambari (REST) - https://.azurehdinsight.net/ambari
trans-unit.target: Ambari (REST) - https://.azurehdinsight.net/ambari

trans-unit.source: Authenticate by using the cluster administrator user and password.
trans-unit.target: Authenticate by using the cluster administrator user and password.

trans-unit.source: Authentication is plaintext - always use HTTPS to help ensure that the connection is secure.
trans-unit.target: Authentication is plaintext - always use HTTPS to help ensure that the connection is secure.

trans-unit.source: WebHCat (Templeton) - https://.azurehdinsight.net/templeton
trans-unit.target: WebHCat (Templeton) - https://.azurehdinsight.net/templeton

trans-unit.source: Authenticate by using the cluster administrator user and password.
trans-unit.target: Authenticate by using the cluster administrator user and password.

trans-unit.source: Authentication is plaintext - always use HTTPS to help ensure that the connection is secure.
trans-unit.target: Authentication is plaintext - always use HTTPS to help ensure that the connection is secure.

trans-unit.source: SSH - -ssh.azurehdinsight.net on port 22 or 23.
trans-unit.target: SSH - -ssh.azurehdinsight.net on port 22 or 23.

trans-unit.source: Port 22 is used to connect to headnode0, while 23 is used to connect to headnode1.
trans-unit.target: Port 22 is used to connect to headnode0, while 23 is used to connect to headnode1.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the head nodes, see <link><linkText>Availability and reliability of Hadoop clusters in HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the head nodes, see <link><linkText>Availability and reliability of Hadoop clusters in HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can only access the cluster head nodes through SSH from a client machine.
trans-unit.target: You can only access the cluster head nodes through SSH from a client machine.

trans-unit.source: Once connected, you can then access the worker nodes by using SSH from the head node.
trans-unit.target: Once connected, you can then access the worker nodes by using SSH from the head node.

trans-unit.source: File locations
trans-unit.target: File locations

trans-unit.source: Hadoop-related files can be found on the cluster nodes at /usr/hdp.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop-related files can be found on the cluster nodes at /usr/hdp.

trans-unit.source: This directory contains the following subdirectories:
trans-unit.target: This directory contains the following subdirectories:

trans-unit.source: 2.2.4.9-1: This directory is named for the version of the Hortonworks Data Platform used by HDInsight, so the number on your cluster may be different than the one listed here.
trans-unit.target: 2.2.4.9-1: This directory is named for the version of the Hortonworks Data Platform used by HDInsight, so the number on your cluster may be different than the one listed here.

trans-unit.source: current: This directory contains links to directories under the 2.2.4.9-1 directory, and exists so that you don't have to type a version number (that might change,) every time you want to access a file.
trans-unit.target: current: This directory contains links to directories under the 2.2.4.9-1 directory, and exists so that you don't have to type a version number (that might change,) every time you want to access a file.

trans-unit.source: Example data and JAR files can be found on Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) or Azure Blob storage at '/example' or 'wasb:///example'.
trans-unit.target: Example data and JAR files can be found on Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) or Azure Blob storage at '/example' or 'wasb:///example'.

trans-unit.source: HDFS, Azure Blob storage, and storage best practices
trans-unit.target: HDFS, Azure Blob storage, and storage best practices

trans-unit.source: In most Hadoop distributions, HDFS is backed by local storage on the machines in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: In most Hadoop distributions, HDFS is backed by local storage on the machines in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: While this is efficient, it can be costly for a cloud-based solution where you are charged hourly for compute resources.
trans-unit.target: While this is efficient, it can be costly for a cloud-based solution where you are charged hourly for compute resources.

trans-unit.source: HDInsight uses Azure Blob storage as the default store, which provides the following benefits:
trans-unit.target: HDInsight uses Azure Blob storage as the default store, which provides the following benefits:

trans-unit.source: Cheap long-term storage
trans-unit.target: Cheap long-term storage

trans-unit.source: Accessibility from external services such as websites, file upload/download utilities, various language SDKs, and web browsers
trans-unit.target: Accessibility from external services such as websites, file upload/download utilities, various language SDKs, and web browsers

trans-unit.source: Since it is the default store for HDInsight, you normally don't have to do anything to use it.
trans-unit.target: Since it is the default store for HDInsight, you normally don't have to do anything to use it.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command will list files in the /example/data folder, which is stored on Azure Blob storage:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command will list files in the /example/data folder, which is stored on Azure Blob storage:

trans-unit.source: Some commands may require you to specify that you are using Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Some commands may require you to specify that you are using Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: For these, you can prefix the command with WASB://.
trans-unit.target: For these, you can prefix the command with WASB://.

trans-unit.source: HDInsight also allows you to associate multiple Blob storage accounts with a cluster.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight also allows you to associate multiple Blob storage accounts with a cluster.

trans-unit.source: To access data on a non-default Blob storage account, you can use the format WASB://@.blob.core.windows.net/.
trans-unit.target: To access data on a non-default Blob storage account, you can use the format WASB://@.blob.core.windows.net/.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following will list the contents of the /example/data directory for the specified container and Blob storage account:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following will list the contents of the /example/data directory for the specified container and Blob storage account:

trans-unit.source: What Blob storage is the cluster using?
trans-unit.target: What Blob storage is the cluster using?

trans-unit.source: During cluster creation, you selected to either use an existing Azure Storage account and container, or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: During cluster creation, you selected to either use an existing Azure Storage account and container, or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: Then, you probably forgot about it.
trans-unit.target: Then, you probably forgot about it.

trans-unit.source: You can find the default storage account and container by using the Ambari REST API.
trans-unit.target: You can find the default storage account and container by using the Ambari REST API.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to retrieve HDFS configuration information:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to retrieve HDFS configuration information:

trans-unit.source: In the JSON data returned, find the fs.defaultFS entry.
trans-unit.target: In the JSON data returned, find the fs.defaultFS entry.

trans-unit.source: This will contain default container and storage account name in a format similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: This will contain default container and storage account name in a format similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: If you have installed jq, you can use the following to return just the fs.defaultFS entry:
trans-unit.target: If you have installed jq, you can use the following to return just the fs.defaultFS entry:

trans-unit.source: curl -u admin:PASSWORD -G "https://CLUSTERNAME.azurehdinsight.net/api/v1/clusters/CLUSTERNAME/configurations/service_config_versions?service_name=HDFS&service_config_version=1" | jq '.items[].configurations[].properties["fs.defaultFS"] | select(. != null)'
trans-unit.target: curl -u admin:PASSWORD -G "https://CLUSTERNAME.azurehdinsight.net/api/v1/clusters/CLUSTERNAME/configurations/service_config_versions?service_name=HDFS&service_config_version=1" | jq '.items[].configurations[].properties["fs.defaultFS"] | select(. != null)'

trans-unit.source: To find the key used to authenticate to the storage account, or to find any secondary storage accounts associated with the cluster, use the following:
trans-unit.target: To find the key used to authenticate to the storage account, or to find any secondary storage accounts associated with the cluster, use the following:

trans-unit.source: In the JSON data returned, find the entries that begin with fs.azure.account.key.
trans-unit.target: In the JSON data returned, find the entries that begin with fs.azure.account.key.

trans-unit.source: The remainder of the entry name is the storage account name.
trans-unit.target: The remainder of the entry name is the storage account name.

trans-unit.source: For example, fs.azure.account.key.mystorage.blob.core.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: For example, fs.azure.account.key.mystorage.blob.core.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: The value stored in this entry is the key used to authenticate to the storage account.
trans-unit.target: The value stored in this entry is the key used to authenticate to the storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you have installed <link><linkText>jq</linkText><title></title></link>, you can use the following to return a list of the keys and values:
trans-unit.target: If you have installed <link><linkText>jq</linkText><title></title></link>, you can use the following to return a list of the keys and values:

trans-unit.source: curl -u admin:PASSWORD -G "https://CLUSTERNAME.azurehdinsight.net/api/v1/clusters/CLUSTERNAME/configurations/service_config_versions?service_name=HDFS&service_config_version=1" | jq '.items[].configurations[].properties as $in | $in | keys[] | select(. | contains("fs.azure.account.key.")) as $item | $item | ltrimstr("fs.azure.account.key.") | { storage_account: ., storage_account_key: $in[$item] }'
trans-unit.target: curl -u admin:PASSWORD -G "https://CLUSTERNAME.azurehdinsight.net/api/v1/clusters/CLUSTERNAME/configurations/service_config_versions?service_name=HDFS&service_config_version=1" | jq '.items[].configurations[].properties as $in | $in | keys[] | select(. | contains("fs.azure.account.key.")) as $item | $item | ltrimstr("fs.azure.account.key.") | { storage_account: ., storage_account_key: $in[$item] }'

trans-unit.source: How do I access Blob storage?
trans-unit.target: How do I access Blob storage?

trans-unit.source: Other than through the Hadoop command from the cluster, there are a variety of ways to access blobs:
trans-unit.target: Other than through the Hadoop command from the cluster, there are a variety of ways to access blobs:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure CLI for Mac, Linux and Windows</linkText><title></title></link>: Command-Line interface commands for working with Azure.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure CLI for Mac, Linux and Windows</linkText><title></title></link>: Command-Line interface commands for working with Azure.

trans-unit.source: After installing, use the azure storage command for help on using storage, or azure blob for blob-specific commands.
trans-unit.target: After installing, use the azure storage command for help on using storage, or azure blob for blob-specific commands.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>blobxfer.py</linkText><title></title></link>: A python script for working with blobs in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>blobxfer.py</linkText><title></title></link>: A python script for working with blobs in Azure Storage.
